BE11:15am

Barclays has been privately exploring a possible merger with rival international banks, including Standard Chartered, in response to pressure from an activist investor who has become one of its biggest shareholders.

The exploratory conversations are part of wide-ranging contingency planning being considered by senior board members in response to the pressure from Edward Bramson’s activist investment fund Sherborne, which recently acquired 5.4 per cent interest in the bank, people briefed on the talks said.

simple simon Any grey on Babcock? BAB.L
2000AD "people briefed on the talks" are talking to journos? Isn't that illegal?

.... and I highly recommend reading the actual story, rather than trusting wires to squeeze the nuance into 60 character flash heads.

Here's Ian Gordon at Investec.

red risk off big time
BE11:20am

We see this as farfetched. Moreover, given STAN’s business
mix, the suggested rationale, as a response to Barclays’ activist interest, makes absolutely no sense to us. All recent M&A activity in the UK banks space has targeted overtly undervalued banks. In our view, that’s not STAN. HOLD.

Pseudonym As in "What a total Barchart that banker is."
red trade talks rolling over, italy drag, german pmi gone from $hit to worse
BE11:21am

Ever since a hostile bid by Lloyds Bank (Buy) for Standard Chartered in 1986, famously thwarted by “three white knights” led by Tan Sri Khoo Teck Puat, there has been perennial takeover speculation. Even if such a combination was credible then, in the context of STAN’s geographic reach and modern-day regulatory complexity,
we see such a transaction as logistically prohibitive.
 At a more basic level, for all its rich history, Standard Chartered currently has a revenue problem, with no cost take-out programme. As such, trading on 0.8x 2018-20e tNAV for 2018-2020e ROTEs of 5.0-7.1%, we struggle to see any material upside on a “standalone” view, and do not see any obvious “strategic fit” with Barclays even if the logistical hurdles could be overcome.

red mkt is v v short bonds
Pharma "Barcered" better (or at least closer to the truth)

As for Barclays, CEO Jes Staley has at least floated the concept of share buybacks. We do not see this as a credible 2018 aspiration, but do expect its CET1 capital ratio to pass back through 13% this year, offering grounds for a legitimate capital surplus distribution debate from 2019. We believe that most Barclays shareholders would be horrified to see this consumed by M&A instead.

red this yr mkt caught short bonds and long euro assets. we are working the latter and its poss spilling into former today. usd rally and em spillage is always fine until it hits US stocks, then you get the risk off bid and everyone covers.

Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 780.10, up 13.2 (+1.72%), High: 787.30, Low: 774.50, Volume: 3.81m

11:25 am
BE11:25am

Morgan Stanley makes similar conclusions .....

BE11:25am

While we understand that management and the board may be contemplating different scenarios, our first take is that such a merger has limited strategic fit given the limited business overlap, and it would be difficult to make it work from a financial point of view given low cost synergies potential and Standard Chartered trading at a premium to Barclays.
The only material overlap in operations is in the UK where Standard Chartered has its HQ, and where central operations could be made more efficient. Standard Chartered has some CIB operations in Asia, but they are limited in scale.

Excel Developer @red, @fatdaz: thanks.
FATDAZ @red thanks for quantifying yen move
BE11:26am

And Jefferies, really going for it.

red watch 3% on the 10 below will trigger lrg covering of shorts. us stocks will gap down on open however, so there is a chance of retracing gap and saving day. if someone steps in to buy.
11:26 am
BE11:26am

. If true, a potential tie-up with STAN would be a mess, in our view.

BE11:27am

First, there is no overlap between the businesses meaning a lack of potential synergies; second, a combination of the two banks would create a bank with an ROTE well below cost of capital (BARC 2020E ROTE 10%; STAN 6-8% depending on revenue outlook) and third, this return inefficiency would be exacerbated by a higher G-SIB capital buffer (BARC currently at 1.5% and STAN at 1.0%) which would constrain any meaningful shareholder return for years to come.

BE11:27am

In our view, any such discussions, if true, reflect dysfunction at the board level as to the forward strategy of the bank and make the prospect for further shareholder activism even more likely.

Excel Developer @fatdaz. @red: do you guys watch CTFC data for clues on positioning?

BE11:28am

And Citi .....

L'Hermitte The Barc/Stan combination makes no sense esp for Stan. A better option for Stan (or for that matter, HSBC), given its franchise in HK & the Pearl delta is to get hold of the Asian/US parts of the Pru.
BE11:28am

We believe that the regulatory changes of the past decade (increased regulatory "balkanisation") and Barclays own strategic divestments (divesting one of the larger African assets of any international bank) make the strategic logic of such a transaction much less interesting today than in 1988 or even 1998

BE11:28am

You get the idea.

Kiwi-juice Banking M&A. If you can buy a bank below tangible book value, at least you are paying a low price, unlike all those banks buying Eastern Europe assets on 5x book before the crisis

The Press Association understands that Costa's owner, Whitbread, which last month said it would split the chain and list it as a separate entity, has been approached informally over a potential buyout of the firm.

Those thought to be considering a move on Costa include heavyweight private equity groups Bain Capital, CVC and TPG, people with knowledge of the matter said.

PA's not usually the go-to source on M&A, and most of that is already known. As we say often, it's very easy to write that buyout firms are considering whether they should buy things because that's literally their jobs.

"has been approached informally" is interesting, though.

Soundbuy informally - no tie and tennis shoes

tangledodyssey Yes. Directors awarded themselves £12m last month, astonishing.
BE11:34am

Merrill cautious, FWIW.

11:34 am
BE11:35am

Despite press reports that there have been 'informal'l PE approaches to Costa' we do not view WTB's valuation as compelling. We believe the current share price assumes a c.9-10x EBITDA acquisition multiple for Costa. A sensitivity analysis suggests 11% upside at 12.0x multiple and 21% at 14x multiple.

BE11:35am

And Credit Suisse.

BE11:36am

We remind investors that as discussed in our February Ideas Engine we see Costa's c30% margin premium to peers as sustainable (given lower cost metrics) plus concluded nothing was in the share price for success with either Costa China or Costa Express. We value Costa at 10x 2019E EBITDA or £2.5bn in our SOTP of c£53, a 14x Feb-19E Bloomberg consensus Starbucks multiple implies £3.4bn or c£58 SOTP, whilst a 20x Panera Bread take out multiple, discussed previously, implies £4.9bn or c£65 SOTP.

Pharma Sigh. I signed up to an online account last week, and today I get an e-mail asking for permission to keep in touch.The joys of GDPR and clueless companies.
11:36 am
BE11:36am

We believe a Costa disposal rather than demerger is an ideal scenario that brings in cash flow that can be used to accelerate growth in Premier Inn Germany. This is the final element of the International story we highlighted in February was potentially being overlooked. That said, a Costa disposal could also be used to remove the pension deficit entirely (Feb-18 deficit £289m) and fund a one-off cash return to shareholders.

BE11:37am

It was commonly observed in April, when Whitbread put a 24 month timeline on the Costa separation, that it looked a lot like inviting bids.

tangledodyssey Thanks, CS take interesting

And informal interest from parties unidentified at this point isn't something the company would be likely to have to comment on. So, we wait. I guess.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Q: How did the results compare vs expectations?
A: FY PBT of £581m was broadly in line. UK profit performance was £10m below UBSe with a weaker Q4 sales outturn and Food gross margin -140bp (UBSe -100bp). UK opex was better at +1.8%. International was c£10m higher than expected at £135m.

Q: What were the most noteworthy areas in the results?
A: "Adjusting items" were higher than we expected at £514m. Acceleration of store closures sees the related charges brought forward into FY18. The pension surplus has risen to £948m, over 20% of market cap.

Q: Has the company's outlook/guidance changed?
A: New FY19 guidance on margin and opex is better: Non-food gross margin 0-50bp (UBSe flat), Food 0-50bp down (UBSe -75bp) and opex -1% (UBSe +1.5%). These give c£130m extra EBIT, although lower space contribution should offset much of this.

Q: How would we expect investors to react?
A: A better outlook on margins and pension assets, plus a stronger dose of realism re the industry outlook, could offset weaker Q4 UK sales trends.

BE11:51am

IAG wants Norwegian to go away due to the threat it creates for transatlantic, and I'm sure if Norwegian just folded IAG would consider that the best possible outcome.

Dec69 - Skeptic @BE, I can answer the Norwegian issue for you, perhaps not how any one else explains it but I'll answer it. The Norwegian pricing point is hurting IAG on various roots, our workings showed they could pay above the odds and recoup quicker with 'pricing' to match supply and demand. I read that as 'increase the hell out of the norwegian pricin[g structure to increase margins across the whole enterprise...Analysts won't have realised how Norwegian has been killing IAG on certain routes...
tangledodyssey But then some other transatlantic start-up would come along
BE11:53am

Buying a stake and saying "sure, we're probably going to buy it any moment now totally maybe" seems a pretty decent strategy if IAG were just looking to be disruptive. Which, to emphasise, is just a hypothetical.

BE11:53am

Anyway, HSBC's selling IAG this morning. Partly on the Gordian knot Norwegian represents.

Dec69 - Skeptic Apologies for roots/routes, its early here.
11:53 am
BE11:53am

We understand the powerful industrial logic for IAG to acquire Norwegian (NAS NO, NOK250.50, Hold) as it would address two of our three core concerns for the IAG equity story – capex challenges from BA’s fleet demographic and Atlantic fragmentation. Moreover, we think there is value in Norwegian’s short-haul order book. However, we think progressing the deal would be complex as multi-player negotiations would play out not just between IAG and Norwegian but also with the potential lessors that are considering acquiring Norwegian’s aircraft and the two aircraft OEMs that we expect would also have veto rights over any deal since aircraft orders of the scale that Norwegian has placed typically have change of control provisions.

FATDAZ @soundbuy Mrs D has been buying almost exclusively from good quality catalogues for the last couple of years I must say its hard to fault quality of lands end T- shirts particularly Supa pima
BE11:54am

We believe that the market has overreacted to the moderate
good news of the Q1 results and seems to be overlooking the pressure from rising fuel prices. We are conceptually enthusiastic about a potential Norwegian transaction. However, we recognise this is a minority view and would expect the markets to react cautiously to the leverage consequences of any acquisition. Conversely, should the deal not go ahead, we would expect more vigorous than ever competition on the North Atlantic between IAG and Norwegian. Yet the execution of an opco/propco deal by Norwegian could help it survive while IAG’s Atlantic profits suffer. We raise our target price for IAG to GBp590 from GBp570 as we lower are estimates and roll forward our valuation period, but we downgrade our rating to Reduce.

FY18 EBITDA at $4.05bn was 3% ahead of Citi and 4%
ahead of company compiled consensus. Underlying EPS at 58.3c was in-line with consensus at 59c but below our 78.3c forecast due to higher minority interest. DPS at 65c was in-line with our 65c forecast. Net debt at $9.6bn was higher than our $8.7bn forecast, primarily due to working capital outflow.

Share price could see negative reaction in similar order of magnitude as subsidiary driven by Tuticorin developments. We have a Buy/High Risk rating, with £8.90/share target price.
